entry.title: If Your App Was Human
entry.content:
Javascript(?) giving your app personality.

First it was about features. Feature war Now it’s about removing features Forget about inventing new experiences. What about cleaning up the existing ones we have to suffer though in our daily lives?

Omnomn helping app. Just built a prototype and the hyperlink made the feeling rather snappy. It was a bit harsh. I wanted to make it smooth and sexy. Or perhaps bouncy and a bit playful. This is the genius of the likes of Steve Jobs and Walt Disney. I felt like I was standing on the shoulders of great men.

I was ready to build.

entry.title: New Format For Plan
entry.content:
App Connections page should look like: https://www.easel.io/documents/e3801d92405f7955#e3801d92405f7955 Finished Campaign analytics should look like: https://www.easel.io/documents/88b0ddec331fb7c1?#88b0ddec331fb7c1

Issue #1: AM is confused when different stats appear in admin blast data vs. in app Issue #2: Customers may be confused by numbers that are displayed w/o an explanation as to what they mean (eg. 2 customer counts). Issue #3: Customers want to see campaign result detail (I thought I had this many customers, why does it say only this many got reached?) Issue #4: Terminology is all over the place. Eg. it’s “Runs from” and “runs to” in one place but “Start” and “end” in another. Issue #5: Still outstanding is to decide how to treat single email/multiple entries. Issue #6: FB fan inclusion into stats Issue #7: Terms need to be defined.

Resolution #1: AM should seldom have to go into admin. Resolution #2: We make it clear which numbers mean what and add tooltips where necessary Resolution #3: Reach is defined as FB+emails+text+bounce Resolution #4: Lets go w/ Start and end when referring to campaigns. Resolution #5: Waiting on Sailesh. Resolution #6: Include Fb fans into stats Resolution #7: I defined some terms.

Quick fix changes:

  1. In admin, replace the words “Aggregate Information” with “Stats” and change that data in admin to reflect same exact data as what is shown to customers Emails: 6089.0; Opens: 940.0; Visits: 285.0; Optouts: 23.0; Bounces: 4.0
  2. In admin, make “Experiment” the same size as the other 2 headers.
  3. In admin, hide Experiments if we are not actively using.
  4. In admin, replace the words “Blast Groups” with “Sent to Mailgun”

entry.title: Doing The Startup Thing
entry.content:
Dear Mom,

San Francisco is a sort of a microcosm in that people from all over the world flock here to “do the startup thing”. Since moving here, I’ve met so many people who’ve traveled far and wide from Europe, Australia, the Midwest, China and more. Why? This is the place where magic happens. Perhaps if you come here, some of the magic will rub off on you too. It sort of reminds me of the time I was in Dubai, where there was no such thing as a shortage of land. They simply created it. Here in the Valley, there’s no shortage of ideas. You simply come up with more. There’s no shame in trying and failing.

The real shame is in not trying at all.

This is what the New Web is all about. Less about what technology can do than what we can do using technology. When you take a careful look, you realize that it’s not the idea that’s the important thing. The idea is secondary. The primary goal here is to simply making something happen. Anything.

As long as we prove something of ourselves.

My college roommate gave me a framed quote from Johann Wolfgang von Goethe which stated “Whatever you can do, or dream you can do, begin it. Boldness has genius, power, and magic in it. Begin it now.”

What the German novelist, dramatist, poet, humanist, scientist, and philosopher was the fundamental fuel of startups. The spirit of the times ignites within each and every one of us the urge to make some sort of impact upon the world. We live in a modern-day renaissance inciting passion and fervor and sense of urgency which is the most exciting thing about being alive.

Here and now.

entry.title: It's All One Big Giant Experiment
Startup Is Fashion
entry.content:
In Los Angeles you hear people talking about blue jeans and sporting the latest fashionable large handbags and sunglasses. Replace the celebrity gossip with excited exchanges on the latest idea, shiny new experiences, and plans to gain traction. San Francisco is quite similar to LA in the sense that both places have a fashion undercurrents in the air. You can’t see it, but you can definitely feel something amiss.

A few properties characterize startups as I’ve observed and experienced from the trenches. Here they are, in no particular order:

  1. Gone: Heavy spec writing.
    Instead: Lightweight, standups instead.

  2. Gone: The unknown corporation.
    Instead: The personable touch.

  3. Gone: Ignoring the customer.
    Instead: The customer is king.

  4. Gone: Poor user experiences.
    Instead: Spotlight on the user experience. Whimsy, personality, fun. Character. This is why copyrighting is so important these days.

  5. Gone: Just build it.
    Instead: Figure out what you will build and market and sell it first. Then build it.

  6. Gone: Silos of demarcatation.
    Instead: Integrated, small design-build teams who can turn on a dime.

  7. Gone: Boring jobs.
    Instead: You can have your cake and eat it too.

  8. Gone: The corporate zombie.
    Instead: The enlightened, self-motivated employee.

  9. Gone: Playing by the rules.
    Intead: Making the rules. Or in some cases, breaking them first.

  10. Gone: Believing you can’t.
    Instead: Believing you can.

  11. Gone: Traditional models and institutions.
    Instead: Forging your own way.

  12. Gone: Traditional glass ceilings.
    Instead: Fuck you money.

All or some of these characteristics may be found in organizations large or small. The beauty is that there’s no reason why one cannot implement one or a few today regardless of what they do for work or what position they are in.
